title: How to Organize Your Household Cleaning Supplies

parts.name: Picking a Location for Your Cleaning Supplies

steps.headline: Store your supplies where they’ll be used.
steps.description: If you have the space, locating them where they get used is often the best solution. Bathroom cleaning supplies might be best stored in the bathroom, kitchen cleaners in the kitchen, and so on. EXPERT TIP																															James Sears																Cleaning Guru								James Sears leads the customer happiness team at Neatly, a group of cleaning gurus based in Los Angeles and Orange County, California. James is an expert in all things clean and provides transformative experiences by reducing clutter and renewing your home environment. James is a current Trustee Scholar at the University of Southern California. James Sears			Cleaning Guru				Our Expert Agrees: Instead of simply having a cleaning closet, try keeping supplies in their respective areas. For instance, you might keep bathroom cleaning supplies in the bathroom or a nearby closet, instead of in a general closet mixed with other cleaning items. That way, your cleaning supplies will stay more organized, they'll be easier to find when you need them, and it's easier to track when you're running low on something.

steps.headline: Store everything in a single location.
steps.description: The suggestion above may not be suitable for a small home, and putting all of your cleaning supplies in a single location may be your only solution. The advantage is that all of your supplies will be easy to find.

steps.headline: Convert a spare closet into a broom closet.
steps.description: Consolidate a couple of partially-filled closets to create one dedicated to cleaning supply storage. Add shelves, racks and hooks to accommodate your cleaning products and tools.

steps.headline: Use extra pantry space.
steps.description: Pantries can often be arranged to create new space for cleaning supplies. Take care not to put food and harmful chemicals in close proximity to one another.

steps.headline: Create a storage area under a stairway.
steps.description: Many homes have unused space under stairways. Utilizing it may be as simple as installing a shelf, or may require a bit of carpentry. Regardless, this is an overlooked option in many homes, and it may make an ideal broom closet.

steps.headline: Create a storage area in the corner of a room.
steps.description: Creative use of modular room dividers, free standing wardrobe cabinets or shelving units can effectively create a new space in an unused area of a room.

steps.headline: Store cleaning supplies on a cart.
steps.description: Push carts and moveable islands are great for both storing supplies and getting them to where they’re needed.

steps.headline: Store cleaning supplies under a sink.
steps.description: The cabinets under kitchen and bathroom sinks are spaces that don’t typically lend themselves to storage of perishable or delicate items, and they’re usually near where cleaning supplies are used.

steps.headline: Store the items you use the most near the front.
steps.description: Don’t waste time looking for what you need in hard to reach places. Organize your supplies so you can grab the ones you want when you need them.

steps.headline: Make it easy to carry your supplies.
steps.description: Store the cleaning products you use most in a basket or caddy, making them easy to grab and take from room to room. If you have the space, consider separate containers for different tasks, such as “dusting,” “waxing,” “bathroom” or “laundry.”

steps.headline: Keep little-used cleaning supplies elsewhere.
steps.description: Storing infrequently used items in a more remote location—such as a basement—keeps them out of your way when you’re looking for a more frequently-used item.

steps.headline: Use a hanging shoe rack to store spray bottles.
steps.description: Hung on the inside of a closet door, this makes a great place to store brushes, dispensers and other cleaning items.

steps.headline: Use a tension rod to hang spray bottles.
steps.description: A spring-loaded curtain rod installed on the inside of a cabinet or closet provides a handy place to hang spray bottles and wet items.

steps.headline: Store your towels in clear storage bins.
steps.description: Plastic bins are perfect for keeping clean dish towels and washrags dry and fresh until you’re ready to use them. This is especially handy under sinks, where it’s often difficult to keep things dry. EXPERT TIP																															James Sears																Cleaning Guru								James Sears leads the customer happiness team at Neatly, a group of cleaning gurus based in Los Angeles and Orange County, California. James is an expert in all things clean and provides transformative experiences by reducing clutter and renewing your home environment. James is a current Trustee Scholar at the University of Southern California. James Sears			Cleaning Guru				Try color-coding your cleaning cloths to keep track of them. When you're buying cleaning cloths, try buying a different color for each use. For example, you might buy green microfiber cloths for the bathroom, white for the kitchen, and blue for everything else. That helps avoid cross-contamination, and it ensures you aren't washing your dishes with a cloth that's been used to clean the bathroom.

steps.headline: Use the Back of a Door.
steps.description: Backs of doors and cabinets are ideal places to look for additional storage. A wide variety of racks, adjustable shelving and modular storage units have become available in recent years. One is likely to be perfect for your existing space.

steps.headline: Store long-handled cleaning tools on a broom holder.
steps.description: These racks can be installed on a wall or door, preventing them from cluttering the floor of your storage space or from falling down constantly.

steps.headline: Put a Lazy Susan under your sink.
steps.description: Installed on a cabinet shelf, they make a great way to get at multiple cleaning items, making sure that nothing gets lost or trapped in the back of the space.

steps.headline: Re-purpose an entire kitchen cabinet.
steps.description: Adding a pull-out pantry to an existing floor-to-ceiling cabinet is a relatively simple fix if you don’t have additional closet space. They can be fitted with a wide variety of shelves and hangers to accommodate a surprising amount of cleaning supplies.

steps.headline: Use multipurpose cleaners.
steps.description: Ask yourself if you really need separate kitchen, bath and laundry surface cleaners, and you may find that you can eliminate several spray bottles and other containers from your cleaning supply inventory.

steps.headline: Eliminate duplicate items.
steps.description: Determine whether or not you really need similar items under the sink in every bathroom, and under the sink in the kitchen, too. Consolidate your glass cleaners. Many people have a spray dispenser with glass cleaner under every bathroom sink. Consider whether you can save space by keeping one bottle in a central location. A single five-gallon bucket may be just as useful as having several buckets in different sizes and in different locations in your home.
